narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A great understanding of the field of sleep science! From the fundamentals of sleep, circadian rhythm's, dreams, sleep disorders, and the public health implications of sleep deprivation, this class offers a great balance of breadth and depth in topics, and leaves students with some helpful sleep-related life hacks.
I learned about sleep.

Knowledge: I learned about the function of sleep, physiological processes that occur during sleep, and the architecture of the sleep cycle. We covered sleep disorders, sleep medicine, and the evolution of sleep research in various fields (animals, dreaming, ...). I also learned about the effects of sleep deprivation, due to insomnia, travel, and poor sleep hygiene.

Skills: analyzing art and literature depicting sleep with a scientific understanding, sleep hygiene skills, how to fight jet lag and insomnia.

Insights: how much sleep do I need? why is sleep important? what happens if I don't sleep well/enough/regularly? how is sleep related to associated health issues? how can I improve my sleep? what is happening during sleep's different stages? how do different animals sleep? how has sleep been represented in art and literature over centuries? how has our understanding/study of sleep evolved over history?
basically, you learn about sleep science

I learned about how humans have learned and understood sleep from the times of the classics to the present. You cover everything up to date about sleep science and how to scientifically comprehend sleep patterns and sleep disorders.
I got a very, very basic understanding of common sleep disorders and of the consequences of sleep deprivation.
Basics of sleep science, humanities, etc.
I learned a lot more about our sleep habits and the science behind our sleep. It was fascinating to learn about such a universal experiences and all of its nuances.
Learned about sleep - science behind it, history, recent developments. Very introductory survey course.
Mostly information regarding the sleep cycle, sleep disorders, sleep hygiene, sleep in art, and the effects of sleep deprivation.

- Sleep history & art
- Sleep disorders
- Healthy sleep & hygiene
- CBT-i
- Insomnia
- Sleep deprivation & consequences
I learned about the science, history, culture, and art behind sleep. I learned about common misconceptions about sleep and the negative ramifications of sleep deprivation, among others.
I learned a lot about sleep skills.
I learned a lot about how sleep is viewed through both a scientific and psychological sense, as well as about the symptoms of sleep disorders.
Learned interesting facts and studies about sleep, some of which were quite applicable to my real life experience.
Taking this class encouraged me to prioritize sleep more this semester.
I learned healthier sleep practices, the functions of sleep, the reasons for dreaming, sleep in animals, effects of drugs on sleep, and how to deal with insomnia.
I learned a lot about sleep that i didnt know before
I learned a ton about the science behind sleep, it was super informative and I find myself applying the information in my every day life often.

- scientific knowledge on the nature of sleep in humans, animals and other species
- gained insight into the complexity of sleep science, how sleep is measured and how sleep science has developed
- learned skills to combat and avoid sleep disorders
Learned about the importance of sleep and its involvement in art, poetry, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: could be improved with clearer guidelines on assignments

Strengths: content, lectures, and professor Kryger! He is great!
Weaknesses: the organization of the class took a while, and the grade breakdown/ whether we had a TF was in question pretty far into the course which left many students confused on the expectations of discussion participation. There is also no feedback on exams which is not helpful in studying for the final.
The lectures were interesting but I wish we went deeper into the anatomy of sleep.

Strengths: interesting and relevant material with important applications in daily life. Great balance of humanities (art, literature, etc) and science. The assignments were creative and enjoyable (term project, discussion posts, term paper), and the lectures were easy to follow.

Weaknesses: the two quizzes/tests were tricky, the class felt a bit disorganized at times with only one weekly meeting lasting an hour.

Strengths:
- Content of the class was interesting
- Professor was very nice

Weaknesses:
- Organized but ended up somewhat disorganized (although this wasn't the fault of the Instructor because Yale did not assign TAs soon enough)
- Powerpoints were good but very big
- Exams always had issues with the questions
strengths are the professor's knowledge, given that he has been in this field for many years and have done a lot of research
I think the strength of this course is the variety of expert lecturers that came during the semester to speak to us about a plethora of subjects related to sleep.

The course was extremely disorganized. The syllabus changed about 5 times throughout the semester, which was very disorienting. Grading standards were unclear. The exams were unexpectedly difficult-- we were told they would only cover material in the lectures (not from optional outside readings), but this often was not the case. There was no guidance on how to prepare for exams, and we had no study materials. There were not set office hour times. The workload was not well distributed-- we had almost no assignments throughout the semester but had a final exam, paper, AND project at the end.
Interesting content, hard to do with a medium sized class. I'd say either make it a big uncapped lecture without discussion or a smaller seminar.
Super great organization, but I think the beginning of this course could use some streamlining. I felt like the first few lectures were much more repetitive than the later ones.
Good science credit. Lots of ways to get points but also kind of boring lectures and wayyyyy too many final assessments (test, group project, AND essay just over finals period).

Strengths: super interesting content, great rotation of instructors who shared their expertise with us. Weaknesses: class format did not encourage much engagement with the course content, and weak connections between the readings/outside work and the content from class.
Strengths: allows for student creativity, discussion. Weaknesses: structure and lecture slides were at times confusing

- Strengths: really interesting & relevant information
- Weaknesses: exams often have random material & ask questions about topics we never discussed
Meir Kryger is a kind and patient professor who guides his students through interesting topics

The course exposed me to a wide variety of topics related to sleep. Although this is a science credit, it was more than just a basic sleep science class. Indeed, we learned about art works and historical depictions of sleep, as well as modern examples of accidents caused by sleep deprivation. 

The course was mostly lecture-based, and I sometimes felt there could have been a more interactive component to the course. We did have discussions, but they were held online on Canvas. I would have preferred a more interactive class.
Classes could be a bit repetitive at times, but I enjoyed the slides.

The content in the class was well-explained, but I wish it was more organized. I also wasnt a fan of the discussions on Thursdays; I felt like I didnt really learn much. I would have rather had class on those days. Also, it was really overwhelming to have to worry about 3 major assignments, especially in the midst of other finals and projects in my other classes, towards the end of the term, and I know other students feel similarly.
Class was somewhat disorganized, but enjoyable. I appreciated that half of classes were replaced with online discussions.

The instructor could not be nicer, but the difficulty of this class is that not much material is presented and its not difficult lesson to lesson, but the tests are then somehow extremely difficult and may include five questions nitpicking on a single topic that wasnt a big focus while skipping some of the major topics that you likely studied.

I think a strength could be to be more specific about what will be on the multiple choice exam bc the questions were supperrrrr broad from all classes and since lectures werent recorded sometimes thered be questions where it was something the prof said not something on slides. Also if we arent able to see what we got wrong which seems counter to learning as we cant actually learn from our mistakes and what we got wrong. All in all i would suggest taking out the multiple choice all together and swapping it with short answer questions instead

The strengths of the course are the variety of guest lecturers, quality of the material, and little to no workload.

A weakness would be no online recording of lectures, so something unclear may not be addressed until the next class.
There are too many final projects

Strengths: Prof Kryger is amazing! He has an amazing handle on the information and is so available and enthusiastic about his students. Also, the material is super interesting
Weaknesses: There are a lot of guest lecturers, with some much more engaging than others. I would prefer to hear more from Professor Kryger than a lot of the guest lecturers.

Strengths:
- spans the mystery of sleep across different disciplines with a focus on science - gave good background and context 
- interactive with discussion boards and in-class discussion
Weaknesses:
- sometimes difficult to distinguish quiz material from additional knowledge
- difficulty practicing for the midterm/exam, no practice material given
Fun class! Met at 4, which made concentrating a little difficult.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, learned a lot of useful info and tips to improve my own sleep. easy science credit.

If you are interested in sleep, you will enjoy this class! It is not the most engaging science class you will find at Yale, but you get out what you put in it, and Dr. Kryger is eager to teach you if you are eager to learn!
Yes! Very multifaceted, interdisciplinary approach to sleep science.
Yes, it is an interesting and enjoyable science course that everyone can learn from, and which makes science accessible to students of all interests and backgrounds.
yes, it is a good class for those looking for a science credit
Yes, by far one of the most interesting courses I've taken at Yale. I love Dr. Kryger. Sleep was such an unknown topic for me and he made it exciting and approachable.
It is a fine option for non-science majors in need of a science credit. I would not take it for fun.
Yes, if you're interesting in the content and willing to manage a bit of an unorthodox workload and course schedule.
Yes but r beware this course has a final exams, project, and paper so it can really sneak up on you at the end.

This is class that would benefit everyone to take. It will help you understand sleep both scientifically and personally. This course is of course a great science credit, but there are lots of STEM majors in the class as well who just want to learn more about sleep because either they or someone they know has a sleeping problem. Great class! And Professor Kryger is just wonderful.
Yes, if you're looking for a good science credit. And you get to learn something about yourself in the process, which is cool.
yep vaguely interesting gut-ish science credit
Yes. Learned a lot about sleep and how it affects our health in unexpected ways.
I think this is an extremely valuable course for anyone who wants to learn more about sleep, regardless of their year and major.
Yes for a gut.
Yes, only good class for non STEM students to fulfill their Sc requirement
Yes if theyre interested in sleep.
Very interesting to learn about sleep. Not as much of a "gut" as you might think, especially for exams.

I would recommend this course to any student who wants to learn more about sleep. I became more conscious about my sleep and sleep hygiene and started to care more about adequate sleep in my daily life. So this is more than just a class; it has the potential to affect one's life style.
It was good to learn about insomnia.
Yes I would. Although I think the class could have been structured better, the material was nonetheless very fascinating and I think most people would benefit from knowing it.
Absolutely.
Yes, it's great for students with little scientific background.

The instructor could not be nicer, but the difficulty of this class is that not much material is presented and its not difficult lesson to lesson, but the tests are then somehow extremely difficult and may include five questions nitpicking on a single topic that wasnt a big focus while skipping some of the major topics that you likely studied.

I took this as a non stem student for my science credit and i would say it is not a gut and is not an easy a. Only a few students get as, the class is curved to ensure this, the multiple choice being 50% of grade it being timed pretty harshly and the questions are pretty complicated makes it so you must go to every class to do well and even then its not guaranteed. The material is definitely super fascinating and professor kygeir is super kind and if you get him to talk about his experience or ask a specific question you can really see the depth of his knowledge. Hi

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student  an expert like Dr. Kryger does an exceptional job at balancing the biology of sleep with humanities-focused elements like art, which keeps the class fun and not boring.
If they need a sci credit
Yes! It's a great science credit if you are not a science major and you actually learn a ton. Professor Kryger cares so much about his students and is always so available.
Yes, for a science credit if the student is interested in sleep. But if the subject matter is not of interest I would not recommend the course as a science credit.
Yes, if you are looking for a science credit, this is a great class to take.
